Title: Paper—Constraint-based Student Modeling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques Constraint-based Student Modeling in Probability Story Problems with Scaffolding Techniques https://doi.org/10.3991/ijet.v13i01.7397
2.2 Description of context: The feedback context is described as providing various forms of assistance, including highlighting keywords related to errors, general feedback on correctness, and specific hints to guide students in correcting their mistakes.
2.3 Our evaluation: The quality of feedback is described as fine-grained, allowing for specific diagnosis of student errors and providing relevant help through visual hints and general feedback.
3.1 Agency type: Students have agency in selecting problems and deciding whether to use scaffolding questions or hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students can control when they receive feedback by choosing to request hints or feedback.

Title: RESEARCH OpenAccess Contextual factors affecting hint utility PaulSalvadorInventado1* ,PeterScupelli1†,KorinnOstrow2†,NeilHeffernanIII2†,JaclynOcumpaugh3†, VictoriaAlmeda4†andStefanSlater3†
2.2 Description of context: The feedback context is described as providing on-demand hints to help students recall relevant concepts, identify mistakes, and make inferences. Correctness feedback is given when students submit answers, indicating whether they are correct or incorrect.
2.3 Our evaluation: The quality of feedback is characterized as potentially effective in improving student performance, particularly when hints are provided early in the problem-solving process.
3.1 Agency type: Students have some agency in requesting hints and controlling their learning process by choosing when to seek help.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students control the timing of feedback by choosing when to request hints.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Metrics used include mastery speed, percent correct, total answer attempts, total hint counts, completion time, and time-on-problem.
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the frequency of hint requests and the types of hints requested (regular vs. bottom-out hints).

Title: Large-Scale Assessments for Learning: A Human-Centred AI Approach to Contextualizing Test Performance

Title: Real-Time AI-Driven Assessment and Scaffolding that Improves Students’ Mathematical Modeling during Science Investigations

Title: The effectiveness of explanatory adaptive feedback within a digital educational game to enhance fraction understanding.pdf

Title: Using Large Language Models To Diagnose Math Problem-solving Skills At Scale HyoungwookJin∗ YoonsuKim∗ YeonSuPark jinhw@kaist.ac.kr yoonsu16@kaist.ac.kr yeonsupark@kaist.ac.kr

Title: Incentivizing supplemental math assignments and using AI-generated hints is associated with improved exam performance
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided in the form of AI-generated hints integrated into homework assignments, aimed at supporting student learning and reducing barriers to seeking help.

3.1 Agency type: Students have agency in choosing to use supplemental math materials and AI-generated hints.
3.2 Feedback timing control: Yes, students can control the timing of when they access feedback (AI-generated hints).

Title: Math”: An Examination of Storylines Circulated by ChatGPT about Mathematical Learners Madeline Day Price
1.2 Context: Classroom, specifically in the context of providing feedback on mathematical writing.

Title: Smart”—How Design of a Digital Tutee’s Self-E cacy ff
1.2 Context: Educational math game, chat interactions after gameplay.
1.4 Tool/Platform: The Squares Family (name of the math game).
2.2 Description of context: Feedback is provided by the digital tutee in the form of chat messages reflecting its self-efficacy (high or low) after gameplay, which influences how students interact with it.
2.3 Our evaluation: The quality of feedback is characterized as recursive, where the tutee's performance reflects the student's teaching effectiveness, and students respond more positively to low self-efficacy feedback.
3.1 Agency type: Students exhibit agency by teaching the digital tutee and responding to its feedback, influencing the interaction.
4.1 Metrics for evaluation: Frequency of responses to feedback, frequency of positive comments, performance on multiple-choice questions, and goodness of card choices during gameplay.
4.2 Measurement of agency: Agency is measured through the frequency and nature of student responses to the tutee's feedback and their engagement in the chat.
